abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Energy Sector
            Loan Project for Pakistan was highly satisfactory. The
            project substantially achieved its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of the Bank
            was highly satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the design of a sectoral reform program
            should involve extensive consultations with the Government,
            as well as potential beneficiaries. Second, the designation
            of a single agency to coordinate policy-making and
            implementation activities under the loan facilitated timely
            decisions, as well as actions by GOP and other entities.
            Third, a continuous dialogue and monitoring of the program
            by GOP and the Bank helped in developing a correspondence of
            views and consistency of policies and strategy. Fourth,
            there is a need for preparatory and continuous training of
            staff in the executing agencies to develop and maintain the
            required procurement skills. Fifth, there is a need for more
            intensive investigation of issues before any agreement on
            the scope and phasing of price rationalization programs is
            reached between GOP and the Bank. Finally, agreements on
            policy reforms should be limited in number, and more
            explicit linkages between priority actions and availability
            of resources should be defined.
